author: Terrence Thomas, Staff Writer
title: Football: Week 9 scouting report
text:

Harlandale coach Isaac Martinez shouts instructions during high school football action against Jefferson at Alamo Stadium on Sept. 12, 2015. Clemens won 56-21. Stevens’ De Vante Donald looks for room around Clemens’ Michael Guevara during second half action on Sept. 11, 2015 at Lehnhoff Stadium. Clemens won 56-21. Photo: Edward A. Brandon Smyth (9) of Brandeis celebrates with teammates Jacob Reyes (76) and Marcos Mullin (52) after scoring a touchdown against Judson during high school football action at Farris Stadium on Sept. 3, 2015. O’Connor receiver Jonathan Tapia catches a touchdown pass during high school football action against Steele’s Imond Woods at Farris Stadium on Sept. 10, 2015. Reagan’s Kyle Anderson sacks Churchill’s Devin Factor causing him to fumble at Comalander Stadium on October 16,2015. Roosevelt’s Elijah Hunter holds onto the jersey of Johnson’s Anthony Hendrix on a run in the second quarter of a District 26-6A high school football game at Comalander Stadium on Oct. 9, 2015. Photo: Ron Cortes /Express-News Football: Week 9 scouting report 1 / 10 
Express-News staff writer Terrence Thomas sets the stage for what to watch for this weekend: 
Key storyline 
Wurst of times: The annual showdown between New Braunfels and New Braunfels Canyon is know as much for its festivities as the game itself. 
When the rivals square off on Friday at New Braunfels Canyon, the contest will carry playoff implications. 
New Braunfels (3-4, 1-2), led by quarterback Trey Martin , is tied with Smithson Valley for fourth place in District 25-6A. With a win, it could set up a key game between the two on Oct. 30. Canyon (2-5, 0-3) needs a victory to keep alive its postseason aspirations. 
New Braunfels leads the all-time series 26-7 and is 7-3 in the last 10 meetings. The schools have split the last four games, with Canyon winning in 2011 and 2013 and New Braunfels in 2012 and 2014. 
Under the radar games 
Sam Houston at Harlandale: 7:30 p.m. Friday — The Hurricanes can lock up their second straight District 28-5A championship with a win on the road. 
Harlandale, however, could create a logjam at the top with a victory, which would be its first against Sam Houston in six meetings. 
Warren vs. Stevens: 7:30 p.m. Friday at Gustafson — The Falcons (6-1, 2-0) have a highly anticipated District 27-6A Zone A showdown next week against Brennan (5-2, 2-0) but must get past Warren (2-5, 1-1) first to make it happen. 
History says it won’t be easy — Warren leads the all-time series 6-3, with Stevens’ last two wins, 2010 and 2014, being by a combined six points. 
By the numbers 
3: Brandeis’ winning streak against O’Connor going into Friday’s showdown for first place in District 27-6A Zone B at Farris Stadium. 
The Broncos (4-3, 2-0) defeated O’Connor 42-3 a year ago, 12-10 on a field goal as time expired and 27-20 in 2012. They have won five of the seven meetings overall. O’Connor (5-2, 2-0) prevailed 35-0 in 2008 and 17-14 in 2011. 
Both teams come into this encounter on four-game winning streaks. 
6: Times in the last 10 meetings that the outcome of the Churchill-Roosevelt game has been decided by seven points or less. 
The teams have split those games, with Roosevelt winning in 2005 (18-17), 2007 (21-14), 2008 (52-7), 2009 (17-14) and 2012 (40-21). Churchill prevailed in 2006 (14-7), 2010 (17-14), 2011 (21-81), 2013 (49-7) and 2014 (38-7). 
The teams meet at 7 p.m. Saturday at Comalander in a contest with postseason implications. 
Churchill (4-3, 1-2) and Roosevelt (3-4, 1-2) are tied for fifth place in District 26-6A, a half-game behind Lee (6-2, 2-2). It’s a logjam that could potential come down to positive points.
